title: 108_s2675
content: CLARIFICATION OF CASH ACCOUNTING RULES FOR SMALL BUSINESS. The Internal Revenue Code allows certain small business taxpayers to use cash accounting method without limitation, as long as they meet specific criteria regarding gross receipts and are not subject to certain sections. The Internal Revenue Code allows small business taxpayers to use cash accounting method if they meet criteria on gross receipts and are not subject to certain sections. The gross receipts test limit is expanded from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000. Inflation adjustment for taxable years after 2005 increases dollar amounts based on cost-of-living adjustments. Inventory rules for small businesses clarified under Section 471 of the Internal Revenue Code. Section 471 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to exempt small business taxpayers from using inventories. Qualified taxpayers are not required to use inventories for a taxable year, and any property not inventoried is treated as a material or supply. The term 'qualified taxpayer' includes eligible taxpayers and those described in section 448(b)(3). Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, removing section 474. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003, and special rules apply to taxpayers changing their accounting method. When a taxpayer changes their accounting method, it is considered initiated by the taxpayer and made with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments required under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code are spread out over a period of up to 4 taxable years. TRANSFER OF UNEMPLOYMENT EXPERIENCE UPON TRANSFER OR ACQUISITION OF A BUSINESS. The Social Security Act is amended to require that if an employer transfers its business to another employer under common ownership, the unemployment experience is also transferred. Unemployment experience cannot be transferred if the acquiring person is not already an employer. The Social Security Act is amended to require the transfer of unemployment experience when a business is acquired for the purpose of obtaining lower contribution rates. Civil and criminal penalties are imposed for violations of these provisions. The Social Security Act is amended to require the transfer of unemployment experience when a business is acquired for lower contribution rates. Penalties are imposed for advising violations of these provisions. The Social Security Act is amended to require the transfer of unemployment experience when a business is acquired for lower contribution rates. Penalties are imposed for violations, and the Secretary of Labor is tasked with studying the implementation of these provisions. Labor will report study findings and recommendations to Congress for improving the effectiveness of section 303(k) of the Social Security Act. The amendment applies to State certifications for payments in rate years after a specified period. Definitions include the terms "State" and "rate year." The curr_chunk defines "rate year" as per State law approved by the Secretary of Labor under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk discusses the use of new hire information to assist in the administration of unemployment compensation programs. Section 453(j) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow State agencies to disclose information from the National Directory of New Hires to assist in administering unemployment compensation programs. The Secretary may disclose information under subparagraph (A) if it does not interfere with program operations. State agencies can only use the information for program administration and must have data security policies approved by the Secretary. State agencies must have data security policies approved by the Secretary to ensure information security and restrict access to authorized persons. Failure to comply may result in sanctions. Requesting agencies must follow uniform procedures. The State agency must adhere to uniform procedures established by the Secretary for information requests and data matching. Reimbursement of costs incurred by the Secretary is required for providing the requested information.
